trans-unit.source: How to use an HTML client | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use an HTML client | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use an HTML client for Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use an HTML client for Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using an HTML/JavaScript client for Azure Mobile Services, which includes Windows Store JavaScript and PhoneGap/Cordova apps.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using an HTML/JavaScript client for Azure Mobile Services, which includes Windows Store JavaScript and PhoneGap/Cordova apps.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include querying for data, inserting, updating, and deleting data, authenticating users, and handling errors.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include querying for data, inserting, updating, and deleting data, authenticating users, and handling errors.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Mobile Services, you should consider first completing the <linkText>Mobile Services quickstart</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Mobile Services, you should consider first completing the <linkText>Mobile Services quickstart</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The quickstart tutorial helps you configure your account and create your first mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The quickstart tutorial helps you configure your account and create your first mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The way that you add a reference to the Mobile Services client depends on your app platform, which includes the following:
trans-unit.target: The way that you add a reference to the Mobile Services client depends on your app platform, which includes the following:

trans-unit.source: For a web-based application, open the HTML file and add the following to the script references for the page:
trans-unit.target: For a web-based application, open the HTML file and add the following to the script references for the page:

trans-unit.source: For a Windows Store app written in JavaScript/HTML, add the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.WinJS NuGet package to your project.
trans-unit.target: For a Windows Store app written in JavaScript/HTML, add the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.WinJS NuGet package to your project.

trans-unit.source: For a PhoneGap or Cordova app, add the <linkText>Mobile Services plugin</linkText><title></title> to your project.
trans-unit.target: For a PhoneGap or Cordova app, add the <linkText>Mobile Services plugin</linkText><title></title> to your project.

trans-unit.source: This plugin supports <linkText>push notifications</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This plugin supports <linkText>push notifications</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the editor, open or create a JavaScript file, and add the following code that defines the MobileServiceClient variable, and supply the application URL and application key from the mobile service in the MobileServiceClient constructor, in that order.
trans-unit.target: In the editor, open or create a JavaScript file, and add the following code that defines the MobileServiceClient variable, and supply the application URL and application key from the mobile service in the MobileServiceClient constructor, in that order.

trans-unit.source: You must replace the placeholder AppUrl with the application URL of your mobile service and AppKey with the application key.
trans-unit.target: You must replace the placeholder AppUrl with the application URL of your mobile service and AppKey with the application key.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to obtain the application URL and application key for the mobile service, consult the tutorial <linkText>Add Mobile Services to an existing app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to obtain the application URL and application key for the mobile service, consult the tutorial <linkText>Add Mobile Services to an existing app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The application key is intended to filter-out random request against your mobile service, and it is distributed with the application.
trans-unit.target: The application key is intended to filter-out random request against your mobile service, and it is distributed with the application.

trans-unit.source: Because this key is not encrypted, it cannot be considered secure.
trans-unit.target: Because this key is not encrypted, it cannot be considered secure.

trans-unit.source: To truly secure your mobile service data, you must instead authenticate users before allowing access.
trans-unit.target: To truly secure your mobile service data, you must instead authenticate users before allowing access.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>How to: Authenticate users</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>How to: Authenticate users</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: All of the code that accesses or modifies data in the SQL Database table calls functions on the MobileServiceTable object.
trans-unit.target: All of the code that accesses or modifies data in the SQL Database table calls functions on the MobileServiceTable object.

trans-unit.source: You get a reference to the table by calling the getTable() function on an instance of the MobileServiceClient.
trans-unit.target: You get a reference to the table by calling the getTable() function on an instance of the MobileServiceClient.

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to filter data by including a where clause in a query.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to filter data by including a where clause in a query.

trans-unit.source: It returns all items from todoItemTable whose complete field is equal to false.
trans-unit.target: It returns all items from todoItemTable whose complete field is equal to false.

trans-unit.source: todoItemTable is the reference to the mobile service table that we created previously.
trans-unit.target: todoItemTable is the reference to the mobile service table that we created previously.

trans-unit.source: The where function applies a row filtering predicate to the query against the table.
trans-unit.target: The where function applies a row filtering predicate to the query against the table.

trans-unit.source: It accepts as its argument a JSON object or function that defines the row filter, and returns a query that can be further composed.
trans-unit.target: It accepts as its argument a JSON object or function that defines the row filter, and returns a query that can be further composed.

trans-unit.source: By adding calling where on the Query object and passing an object as a parameter, we are instructing Mobile Services to return only the rows whose complete column contains the false value.
trans-unit.target: By adding calling where on the Query object and passing an object as a parameter, we are instructing Mobile Services to return only the rows whose complete column contains the false value.

trans-unit.source: Also, look at the request URI below, and notice that we are modifying the query string itself:
trans-unit.target: Also, look at the request URI below, and notice that we are modifying the query string itself:

trans-unit.source: You can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service by using message inspection software, such as browser developer tools or Fiddler.
trans-unit.target: You can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service by using message inspection software, such as browser developer tools or Fiddler.

trans-unit.source: This request would normally be translated roughly into the following SQL query on the server side:
trans-unit.target: This request would normally be translated roughly into the following SQL query on the server side:

trans-unit.source: The object which is passed to the where method can have an arbitrary number of parameters, and they'll all be interpreted as AND clauses to the query.
trans-unit.target: The object which is passed to the where method can have an arbitrary number of parameters, and they'll all be interpreted as AND clauses to the query.

trans-unit.source: For example, the line below:
trans-unit.target: For example, the line below:

trans-unit.source: Would be roughly translated (for the same request shown before) as
trans-unit.target: Would be roughly translated (for the same request shown before) as

trans-unit.source: The where statement above and the SQL query above find incomplete items assigned to "david" of "medium" difficulty.
trans-unit.target: The where statement above and the SQL query above find incomplete items assigned to "david" of "medium" difficulty.

trans-unit.source: There is, however, another way to write the same query.
trans-unit.target: There is, however, another way to write the same query.

trans-unit.source: A .where call on the Query object will add an AND expression to the WHERE clause, so we could have written that in three lines instead:
trans-unit.target: A .where call on the Query object will add an AND expression to the WHERE clause, so we could have written that in three lines instead:

trans-unit.source: Or using the fluent API:
trans-unit.target: Or using the fluent API:

trans-unit.source: The two methods are equivalent and may be used interchangeably.
trans-unit.target: The two methods are equivalent and may be used interchangeably.

trans-unit.source: All the where calls so far take an object with some parameters, and are compared for equality against the data from the database.
trans-unit.target: All the where calls so far take an object with some parameters, and are compared for equality against the data from the database.

trans-unit.source: There is, however, another overload for the query method, which takes a function instead of the object.
trans-unit.target: There is, however, another overload for the query method, which takes a function instead of the object.

trans-unit.source: In this function we can then write more complex expressions, using operators such as inequality and other relational operations.
trans-unit.target: In this function we can then write more complex expressions, using operators such as inequality and other relational operations.

trans-unit.source: In these functions, the keyword this binds to the server object.
trans-unit.target: In these functions, the keyword this binds to the server object.

trans-unit.source: The body of the function is translated into an Open Data Protocol (OData) boolean expression which is passed to a query string parameter.
trans-unit.target: The body of the function is translated into an Open Data Protocol (OData) boolean expression which is passed to a query string parameter.

trans-unit.source: It is possible to pass in a function that takes no parameters, like so:
trans-unit.target: It is possible to pass in a function that takes no parameters, like so:

trans-unit.source: If passing in a function with parameters, any arguments after the where clause are bound to the function parameters in order.
trans-unit.target: If passing in a function with parameters, any arguments after the where clause are bound to the function parameters in order.

trans-unit.source: Any objects which come from the outside of the function scope MUST be passed as parameters - the function cannot capture any external variables.
trans-unit.target: Any objects which come from the outside of the function scope MUST be passed as parameters - the function cannot capture any external variables.

trans-unit.source: In the next two examples, the argument "david" is bound to the parameter name and in the first example, the argument "medium" is also bound to the parameter level.
trans-unit.target: In the next two examples, the argument "david" is bound to the parameter name and in the first example, the argument "medium" is also bound to the parameter level.

trans-unit.source: Also, the function must consist of a single return statement with a supported expression, like so:
trans-unit.target: Also, the function must consist of a single return statement with a supported expression, like so:

trans-unit.source: So, as long as we follow the rules, we can add more complex filters to our database queries, like so:
trans-unit.target: So, as long as we follow the rules, we can add more complex filters to our database queries, like so:

trans-unit.source: It is possible to combine where with orderBy, take, and skip.
trans-unit.target: It is possible to combine where with orderBy, take, and skip.

trans-unit.source: See the next section for details.
trans-unit.target: See the next section for details.

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to sort data by including an orderBy or orderByDescending function in the query.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to sort data by including an orderBy or orderByDescending function in the query.

trans-unit.source: It returns items from todoItemTable sorted ascending by the text field.
trans-unit.target: It returns items from todoItemTable sorted ascending by the text field.

trans-unit.source: By default, the server returns only the first 50 elements.
trans-unit.target: By default, the server returns only the first 50 elements.

trans-unit.source: A server-driven page size us used by default to prevent all elements from being returned.
trans-unit.target: A server-driven page size us used by default to prevent all elements from being returned.

trans-unit.source: This keeps default requests for large data sets from negatively impacting the service.
trans-unit.target: This keeps default requests for large data sets from negatively impacting the service.

trans-unit.source: You may increase the number of items to be returned by calling take as described in the next section.
trans-unit.target: You may increase the number of items to be returned by calling take as described in the next section.

trans-unit.source: todoItemTable is the reference to the mobile service table that we created previously.
trans-unit.target: todoItemTable is the reference to the mobile service table that we created previously.

trans-unit.source: By default, Mobile Services only returns 50 rows in a given request, unless the client explicitly asks for more data in the response.
trans-unit.target: By default, Mobile Services only returns 50 rows in a given request, unless the client explicitly asks for more data in the response.

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to implement paging in returned data by using the take and skip clauses in the query.
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to implement paging in returned data by using the take and skip clauses in the query.

trans-unit.source: The following query, when executed, returns the top three items in the table.
trans-unit.target: The following query, when executed, returns the top three items in the table.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the take(3) method was translated into the query option $top=3 in the query URI.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the take(3) method was translated into the query option $top=3 in the query URI.

trans-unit.source: The following revised query skips the first three results and returns the next three after that.
trans-unit.target: The following revised query skips the first three results and returns the next three after that.

trans-unit.source: This is effectively the second "page" of data, where the page size is three items.
trans-unit.target: This is effectively the second "page" of data, where the page size is three items.

trans-unit.source: Again, you can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Again, you can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the skip(3) method was translated into the query option $skip=3 in the query URI.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the skip(3) method was translated into the query option $skip=3 in the query URI.

trans-unit.source: This is a simplified scenario of passing hard-coded paging values to the take and skip functions.
trans-unit.target: This is a simplified scenario of passing hard-coded paging values to the take and skip functions.

trans-unit.source: In a real-world app, you can use queries similar to the above with a pager control or comparable UI to let users navigate to previous and next pages.
trans-unit.target: In a real-world app, you can use queries similar to the above with a pager control or comparable UI to let users navigate to previous and next pages.

trans-unit.source: You can specify which set of properties to include in the results by adding a select clause to your query.
trans-unit.target: You can specify which set of properties to include in the results by adding a select clause to your query.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code returns the id, complete, and text properties from each row in the todoItemTable:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code returns the id, complete, and text properties from each row in the todoItemTable:

trans-unit.source: Here the parameters to the select function are the names of the table's columns that you want to return.
trans-unit.target: Here the parameters to the select function are the names of the table's columns that you want to return.

trans-unit.source: All the functions described so far are additive, so we can just keep calling them and we'll each time affect more of the query.
trans-unit.target: All the functions described so far are additive, so we can just keep calling them and we'll each time affect more of the query.

trans-unit.source: One more example:
trans-unit.target: One more example:

trans-unit.source: The lookup function takes only the id value, and returns the object from the database with that ID.
trans-unit.target: The lookup function takes only the id value, and returns the object from the database with that ID.

trans-unit.source: Database tables are created with either an integer or string id column.
trans-unit.target: Database tables are created with either an integer or string id column.

trans-unit.source: A string id column is the default.
trans-unit.target: A string id column is the default.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services uses the OData query URI conventions for composing and executing REST queries.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services uses the OData query URI conventions for composing and executing REST queries.

trans-unit.source: Not all OData queries can be composed by using the built-in query functions, especially complex filter operations like searching for a substring in a property.
trans-unit.target: Not all OData queries can be composed by using the built-in query functions, especially complex filter operations like searching for a substring in a property.

trans-unit.source: For these kinds of complex queries, you can pass any valid OData query option string to the read function, as follows:
trans-unit.target: For these kinds of complex queries, you can pass any valid OData query option string to the read function, as follows:

trans-unit.source: When you provide a raw OData query option string into the read function, you cannot also use the query builder methods in the same query.
trans-unit.target: When you provide a raw OData query option string into the read function, you cannot also use the query builder methods in the same query.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you must compose your whole query as an OData query string.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you must compose your whole query as an OData query string.

trans-unit.source: For more information on OData system query options, see the [OData system query options reference].
trans-unit.target: For more information on OData system query options, see the [OData system query options reference].

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to insert new rows into a table.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to insert new rows into a table.

trans-unit.source: The client requests that a row of data be inserted by sending a POST request to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The client requests that a row of data be inserted by sending a POST request to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The request body contains the data to be inserted, as a JSON object.
trans-unit.target: The request body contains the data to be inserted, as a JSON object.

trans-unit.source: This inserts data from the supplied JSON object into the table.
trans-unit.target: This inserts data from the supplied JSON object into the table.

trans-unit.source: You can also specify a callback function to be invoked when the insertion is complete:
trans-unit.target: You can also specify a callback function to be invoked when the insertion is complete:

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services supports unique custom string values for the table's id column.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services supports unique custom string values for the table's id column.

trans-unit.source: This allows applications to use custom values such as email addresses or user names for the ID.
trans-unit.target: This allows applications to use custom values such as email addresses or user names for the ID.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code inserts a new item as a JSON object, where the unique ID is an email address:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code inserts a new item as a JSON object, where the unique ID is an email address:

trans-unit.source: String IDs provide you with the following benefits:
trans-unit.target: String IDs provide you with the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: IDs are generated without making a round-trip to the database.
trans-unit.target: IDs are generated without making a round-trip to the database.

trans-unit.source: Records are easier to merge from different tables or databases.
trans-unit.target: Records are easier to merge from different tables or databases.

trans-unit.source: IDs values can integrate better with an application's logic.
trans-unit.target: IDs values can integrate better with an application's logic.

trans-unit.source: When a string ID value is not already set on an inserted record, Mobile Services generates a unique value for the ID.
trans-unit.target: When a string ID value is not already set on an inserted record, Mobile Services generates a unique value for the ID.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to generate your own ID values, either on the client or in a .NET backend, see <linkText>How to: Generate unique ID values</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to generate your own ID values, either on the client or in a .NET backend, see <linkText>How to: Generate unique ID values</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can also use integer IDs for your tables.
trans-unit.target: You can also use integer IDs for your tables.

trans-unit.source: To use an integer ID, you must create your table with the mobile table create command using the --integerId option.
trans-unit.target: To use an integer ID, you must create your table with the mobile table create command using the --integerId option.

trans-unit.source: This command is used with the Command-line Interface (CLI) for Azure.
trans-unit.target: This command is used with the Command-line Interface (CLI) for Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using the CLI, see <linkText>CLI to manage Mobile Services tables</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on using the CLI, see <linkText>CLI to manage Mobile Services tables</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to update data in a table.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to update data in a table.

trans-unit.source: The client requests that a row of data be updated by sending a PATCH request to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The client requests that a row of data be updated by sending a PATCH request to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The request body contains the specific fields to be updated, as a JSON object.
trans-unit.target: The request body contains the specific fields to be updated, as a JSON object.

trans-unit.source: It updates an existing item in the table todoItemTable.
trans-unit.target: It updates an existing item in the table todoItemTable.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter specifies the instance to update in the table, as specified by its ID.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter specifies the instance to update in the table, as specified by its ID.

trans-unit.source: You can also specify a callback function to be invoked when the update is complete:
trans-unit.target: You can also specify a callback function to be invoked when the update is complete:

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to delete data from a table.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to delete data from a table.

trans-unit.source: The client requests that a row of data be deleted by sending a DELETE request to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The client requests that a row of data be deleted by sending a DELETE request to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: It deletes an existing item in the table todoItemTable.
trans-unit.target: It deletes an existing item in the table todoItemTable.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter specifies the instance to delete in the table, as specified by its ID.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter specifies the instance to delete in the table, as specified by its ID.

trans-unit.source: You can also specify a callback function to be invoked when the delete is complete:
trans-unit.target: You can also specify a callback function to be invoked when the delete is complete:

trans-unit.source: This section shows how to display returned data objects using UI elements.
trans-unit.target: This section shows how to display returned data objects using UI elements.

trans-unit.source: To query items in todoItemTable and display it in a very simple list, you can run the following example code.
trans-unit.target: To query items in todoItemTable and display it in a very simple list, you can run the following example code.

trans-unit.source: No selection, filtering or sorting of any kind is done.
trans-unit.target: No selection, filtering or sorting of any kind is done.

trans-unit.source: In a Windows Store app, the results of a query can be used to create a [WinJS.Binding.List] object, which can be bound as the data source for a [ListView] object.
trans-unit.target: In a Windows Store app, the results of a query can be used to create a [WinJS.Binding.List] object, which can be bound as the data source for a [ListView] object.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Data binding (Windows Store apps using JavaScript and HTML)].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Data binding (Windows Store apps using JavaScript and HTML)].

trans-unit.source: A custom API enables you to define custom endpoints that expose server functionality that does not map to an insert, update, delete, or read operation.
trans-unit.target: A custom API enables you to define custom endpoints that expose server functionality that does not map to an insert, update, delete, or read operation.

trans-unit.source: By using a custom API, you can have more control over messaging, including reading and setting HTTP message headers and defining a message body format other than JSON.
trans-unit.target: By using a custom API, you can have more control over messaging, including reading and setting HTTP message headers and defining a message body format other than JSON.

trans-unit.source: For a complete example, including how to create a custom API in your mobile service, see [Call a custom API from the client].
trans-unit.target: For a complete example, including how to create a custom API in your mobile service, see [Call a custom API from the client].

trans-unit.source: You call a custom API from the client by calling the invokeApi method on MobileServiceClient.
trans-unit.target: You call a custom API from the client by calling the invokeApi method on MobileServiceClient.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following line of code sends a POST request to the completeAll API on the mobile service:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following line of code sends a POST request to the completeAll API on the mobile service:

trans-unit.source: For more realistic examples and a more a complete discussion of invokeApi, see Custom API in Azure Mobile Services Client SDKs.
trans-unit.target: For more realistic examples and a more a complete discussion of invokeApi, see Custom API in Azure Mobile Services Client SDKs.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services supports authenticating and authorizing app users using a variety of external identity providers: Facebook, Google, Microsoft Account, and Twitter.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services supports authenticating and authorizing app users using a variety of external identity providers: Facebook, Google, Microsoft Account, and Twitter.

trans-unit.source: You can set permissions on tables to restrict access for specific operations to only authenticated users.
trans-unit.target: You can set permissions on tables to restrict access for specific operations to only authenticated users.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the identity of authenticated users to implement authorization rules in server scripts.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the identity of authenticated users to implement authorization rules in server scripts.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Get started with authentication] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Get started with authentication] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: When using authentication in a PhoneGap or Cordova app, you must also add the following plugins to the project:
trans-unit.target: When using authentication in a PhoneGap or Cordova app, you must also add the following plugins to the project:

trans-unit.source: https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/cordova-plugin-device.git
trans-unit.target: https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/cordova-plugin-device.git

trans-unit.source: https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/cordova-plugin-inappbrowser.git
trans-unit.target: https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/cordova-plugin-inappbrowser.git

trans-unit.source: Two authentication flows are supported: a server flow and a client flow.
trans-unit.target: Two authentication flows are supported: a server flow and a client flow.

trans-unit.source: The server flow provides the simplest authentication experience, as it relies on the provider's web authentication interface.
trans-unit.target: The server flow provides the simplest authentication experience, as it relies on the provider's web authentication interface.

trans-unit.source: The client flow allows for deeper integration with device-specific capabilities such as single-sign-on as it relies on provider-specific device-specific SDKs.
trans-unit.target: The client flow allows for deeper integration with device-specific capabilities such as single-sign-on as it relies on provider-specific device-specific SDKs.

trans-unit.source: To have Mobile Services manage the authentication process in your Windows Store or HTML5 app, you must register your app with your identity provider.
trans-unit.target: To have Mobile Services manage the authentication process in your Windows Store or HTML5 app, you must register your app with your identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Then in your mobile service, you need to configure the application ID and secret provided by your provider.
trans-unit.target: Then in your mobile service, you need to configure the application ID and secret provided by your provider.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the tutorial <linkText>Add authentication to your app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the tutorial <linkText>Add authentication to your app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once you have registered your identity provider, simply call the [LoginAsync method] with the [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] value of your provider.
trans-unit.target: Once you have registered your identity provider, simply call the [LoginAsync method] with the [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] value of your provider.

trans-unit.source: For example, to login with Facebook use the following code.
trans-unit.target: For example, to login with Facebook use the following code.

trans-unit.source: If you are using an identity provider other than Facebook, change the value passed to the login method above to one of the following: microsoftaccount, facebook, twitter, google, or windowsazureactivedirectory.
trans-unit.target: If you are using an identity provider other than Facebook, change the value passed to the login method above to one of the following: microsoftaccount, facebook, twitter, google, or windowsazureactivedirectory.

trans-unit.source: In this case, Mobile Services manages the OAuth 2.0 authentication flow by displaying the login page of the selected provider and generating a Mobile Services authentication token after successful login with the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In this case, Mobile Services manages the OAuth 2.0 authentication flow by displaying the login page of the selected provider and generating a Mobile Services authentication token after successful login with the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: The [login] function, when complete, returns a JSON object (user) that exposes both the user ID and Mobile Services authentication token in the userId and authenticationToken fields, respectively.
trans-unit.target: The [login] function, when complete, returns a JSON object (user) that exposes both the user ID and Mobile Services authentication token in the userId and authenticationToken fields, respectively.

trans-unit.source: This token can be cached and re-used until it expires.
trans-unit.target: This token can be cached and re-used until it expires.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Caching the authentication token].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Caching the authentication token].

trans-unit.source: Windows Store app When you use the Microsoft Account login provider to authenticate users of your Windows Store app, you should also register the app package with Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Windows Store app When you use the Microsoft Account login provider to authenticate users of your Windows Store app, you should also register the app package with Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: When you register your Windows Store app package information with Mobile Services, the client is able to re-use Microsoft Account login credentials for a single sign-on experience.
trans-unit.target: When you register your Windows Store app package information with Mobile Services, the client is able to re-use Microsoft Account login credentials for a single sign-on experience.

trans-unit.source: If you do not do this, your Microsoft Account login users will be presented with a login prompt every time that the login method is called.
trans-unit.target: If you do not do this, your Microsoft Account login users will be presented with a login prompt every time that the login method is called.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to register your Windows Store app package, see <linkText>Register your Windows Store app package for Microsoft authentication</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to register your Windows Store app package, see <linkText>Register your Windows Store app package for Microsoft authentication</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: After the package information is registered with Mobile Services, call the login method by supplying a value of true for the useSingleSignOn parameter to re-use the credentials.
trans-unit.target: After the package information is registered with Mobile Services, call the login method by supplying a value of true for the useSingleSignOn parameter to re-use the credentials.

trans-unit.source: Your app can also independently contact the identity provider and then provide the returned token to Mobile Services for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Your app can also independently contact the identity provider and then provide the returned token to Mobile Services for authentication.

trans-unit.source: This client flow enables you to provide a single sign-in experience for users or to retrieve additional user data from the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: This client flow enables you to provide a single sign-in experience for users or to retrieve additional user data from the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the Live SDK, which supports single-sign-on for Windows Store apps by using Microsoft Account:
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the Live SDK, which supports single-sign-on for Windows Store apps by using Microsoft Account:

trans-unit.source: This simplified example gets a token from Live Connect, which is supplied to Mobile Services by calling the [login] function.
trans-unit.target: This simplified example gets a token from Live Connect, which is supplied to Mobile Services by calling the [login] function.

trans-unit.source: For a more complete example of how to use Microsoft Account to provide a single sign-in experience, see [Authenticate your app with single sign-in].
trans-unit.target: For a more complete example of how to use Microsoft Account to provide a single sign-in experience, see [Authenticate your app with single sign-in].

trans-unit.source: When you are using the Facebook or Google APIs for client authentication, the example changes slightly.
trans-unit.target: When you are using the Facebook or Google APIs for client authentication, the example changes slightly.

trans-unit.source: This example assumes that the token provided by the respective provider SDK is stored in the token variable.
trans-unit.target: This example assumes that the token provided by the respective provider SDK is stored in the token variable.

trans-unit.source: Twitter cannot be used for client authentication at this time.
trans-unit.target: Twitter cannot be used for client authentication at this time.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Active Directory cannot be used with JavaScript backends for client authentication at this time.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Active Directory cannot be used with JavaScript backends for client authentication at this time.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, the call to the login method can be avoided after the first time the user authenticates.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, the call to the login method can be avoided after the first time the user authenticates.

trans-unit.source: We can use [sessionStorage] or [localStorage] to cache the current user identity the first time they log in and every subsequent time we check whether we already have the user identity in our cache.
trans-unit.target: We can use [sessionStorage] or [localStorage] to cache the current user identity the first time they log in and every subsequent time we check whether we already have the user identity in our cache.

trans-unit.source: If the cache is empty or calls fail (meaning the current login session has expired), we still need to go through the login process.
trans-unit.target: If the cache is empty or calls fail (meaning the current login session has expired), we still need to go through the login process.

trans-unit.source: When your app is a PhoneGap or Apache Cordova HTML/JavaScript app, the native mobile platform enables you to receive push notifications on the device.
trans-unit.target: When your app is a PhoneGap or Apache Cordova HTML/JavaScript app, the native mobile platform enables you to receive push notifications on the device.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Apache Cordova plugin for Azure Mobile Services</linkText><title></title> enables you to register for push notifications with Azure Notification Hubs.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Apache Cordova plugin for Azure Mobile Services</linkText><title></title> enables you to register for push notifications with Azure Notification Hubs.

trans-unit.source: The specific notification service used depends on the native device platform on which the code executes.
trans-unit.target: The specific notification service used depends on the native device platform on which the code executes.

trans-unit.source: For an example of how to do this, see the sample, <linkText>Use Microsoft Azure to push notifications to Cordova apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an example of how to do this, see the sample, <linkText>Use Microsoft Azure to push notifications to Cordova apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This plugin currently only supports iOS and Android devices.
trans-unit.target: This plugin currently only supports iOS and Android devices.

trans-unit.source: For a solution that also includes Windows devices, see the article <linkText>Push Notifications to PhoneGap Apps using Notification Hubs Integration</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a solution that also includes Windows devices, see the article <linkText>Push Notifications to PhoneGap Apps using Notification Hubs Integration</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to encounter, validate, and work around errors in Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to encounter, validate, and work around errors in Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: As an example, server scripts are registered in a mobile service and can be used to perform a wide range of operations on data being inserted and updated, including validation and data modification.
trans-unit.target: As an example, server scripts are registered in a mobile service and can be used to perform a wide range of operations on data being inserted and updated, including validation and data modification.

trans-unit.source: Imagine defining and registering a server script that validate and modify data, like so:
trans-unit.target: Imagine defining and registering a server script that validate and modify data, like so:

trans-unit.source: This server-side script validates the length of string data sent to the mobile service and rejects strings that are too long, in this case longer than 10 characters.
trans-unit.target: This server-side script validates the length of string data sent to the mobile service and rejects strings that are too long, in this case longer than 10 characters.

trans-unit.source: Now that the mobile service is validating data and sending error responses on the server-side, you can update your HTML app to be able to handle error responses from validation.
trans-unit.target: Now that the mobile service is validating data and sending error responses on the server-side, you can update your HTML app to be able to handle error responses from validation.

trans-unit.source: To tease this out even further, you pass in the error handler as the second argument each time you perform data access:
trans-unit.target: To tease this out even further, you pass in the error handler as the second argument each time you perform data access:

trans-unit.source: Promises provide a mechanism to schedule work to be done on a value that has not yet been computed.
trans-unit.target: Promises provide a mechanism to schedule work to be done on a value that has not yet been computed.

trans-unit.source: It is an abstraction for managing interactions with asynchronous APIs.
trans-unit.target: It is an abstraction for managing interactions with asynchronous APIs.

trans-unit.source: The done promise is executed as soon as the function provided to it has either successfully completed or has gotten an error.
trans-unit.target: The done promise is executed as soon as the function provided to it has either successfully completed or has gotten an error.

trans-unit.source: Unlike the then promise, it is guaranteed to throw any error that is not handled inside the function, and after the handlers have finished executing, this function throws any error that would have been returned from then as a promise in the error state.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the then promise, it is guaranteed to throw any error that is not handled inside the function, and after the handlers have finished executing, this function throws any error that would have been returned from then as a promise in the error state.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [done].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [done].

trans-unit.source: Like so:
trans-unit.target: Like so:

trans-unit.source: The then promise is the same as the as the done promise, but unlike the then promise, done is guaranteed to throw any error that is not handled inside the function.
trans-unit.target: The then promise is the same as the as the done promise, but unlike the then promise, done is guaranteed to throw any error that is not handled inside the function.

trans-unit.source: If you do not provide an error handler to then and the operation has an error, it does not throw an exception but rather returns a promise in the error state.
trans-unit.target: If you do not provide an error handler to then and the operation has an error, it does not throw an exception but rather returns a promise in the error state.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [then].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [then].

trans-unit.source: Like so:
trans-unit.target: Like so:

trans-unit.source: You can use promises in a number of different ways.
trans-unit.target: You can use promises in a number of different ways.

trans-unit.source: You can chain promise operations by calling then or done on the promise that is returned by the previous then function.
trans-unit.target: You can chain promise operations by calling then or done on the promise that is returned by the previous then function.

trans-unit.source: Use then for an intermediate stage of the operation (for example .then().then()), and done for the final stage of the operation (for example .then().then().done()).
trans-unit.target: Use then for an intermediate stage of the operation (for example .then().then()), and done for the final stage of the operation (for example .then().then().done()).

trans-unit.source: You can chain multiple then functions, because then returns a promise.
trans-unit.target: You can chain multiple then functions, because then returns a promise.

trans-unit.source: You cannot chain more than one done method, because it returns undefined.
trans-unit.target: You cannot chain more than one done method, because it returns undefined.

trans-unit.source: [Learn more about the differences between then and done].
trans-unit.target: [Learn more about the differences between then and done].

trans-unit.source: You can send custom request headers using the withFilter function, reading and writing arbitrary properties of the request about to be sent within the filter.
trans-unit.target: You can send custom request headers using the withFilter function, reading and writing arbitrary properties of the request about to be sent within the filter.

trans-unit.source: You may want to add such a custom HTTP header if a server-side script needs it or may be enhanced by it.
trans-unit.target: You may want to add such a custom HTTP header if a server-side script needs it or may be enhanced by it.

trans-unit.source: Filters are used for a lot more than customizing request headers.
trans-unit.target: Filters are used for a lot more than customizing request headers.

trans-unit.source: They can be used to examine or change requests, examine or change responses, bypass networking calls, send multiple calls, etc.
trans-unit.target: They can be used to examine or change requests, examine or change responses, bypass networking calls, send multiple calls, etc.

trans-unit.source: To control which websites are allowed to interact with and send requests to your mobile service, make sure to add the host name of the website you use to host it to the Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) whitelist.
trans-unit.target: To control which websites are allowed to interact with and send requests to your mobile service, make sure to add the host name of the website you use to host it to the Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) whitelist.

trans-unit.source: For a JavaScript backend mobile service, you can configure the whitelist on the Configure tab in the <linkText>Azure Management portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a JavaScript backend mobile service, you can configure the whitelist on the Configure tab in the <linkText>Azure Management portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can use wildcards if required.
trans-unit.target: You can use wildcards if required.

trans-unit.source: By default, new Mobile Services instruct browsers to permit access only from localhost, and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) allows JavaScript code running in a browser on an external hostname to interact with your Mobile Service.
trans-unit.target: By default, new Mobile Services instruct browsers to permit access only from localhost, and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) allows JavaScript code running in a browser on an external hostname to interact with your Mobile Service.

trans-unit.source: This configuration is not necessary for WinJS applications.
trans-unit.target: This configuration is not necessary for WinJS applications.
